Fig 10 Boosting the polysulfide confinement in B/N–codoped hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets via Lewis acid–base interaction for stable Li–S batteries Dong–Gen Xiong Ze Zhang Xiao–Yun Huang Yan Huang Ji Yu Jian–Xin Cai Zhen–Yu Yang ⁎ College of Chemistry, Key laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Environment and Energy Catalysis, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, Jiangxi, China College of Chemistry Key laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Environment and Energy Catalysis Nanchang University Nanchang Jiangxi 330031 China College of Chemistry, Key laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Environment and Energy Catalysis, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, Jiangxi, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Carbon materials have shown remarkable usefulness in facilitating the performance of insulating sulfur cathode for lithium–sulfur batteries owing to their excellent conductivity and porous structure. However, the anxiety is the poor affinity toward polar polysulfides due to the intrinsic nonpolar surface of carbon. Herein, we report a direct pyrolysis of the mixture urea and boric acid to synthesize B/N–codoped hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets (B–N–CSs) as efficient sulfur host for lithium–sulfur battery. The graphene–like B–N–CSs provides high specific surface area and porous structure with abundant micropores (1.1 nm) and low–range mesopores (2.3 nm), thereby constraining the sulfur active materials within the pores. More importantly, the codoped B/N elements can further enhance the polysulfide confinement through strong Li–N and B–S interaction based on the Lewis acid–base theory. These structural superiorities significantly suppress the shuttle effect by both physical confinement and chemical interaction, and promote the redox kinetics of polysulfide conversion. When evaluated as the cathode host, the S/B–N–CSs composite displays the excellent performance with a high reversible capacity up to 772 mA h g–1 at 0.5 C and a low fading rate of ~0.09% per cycle averaged upon 500 cycles. In particular, remarkable stability with a high capacity retention of 87.1% can be realized when augmenting the sulfur loading in the cathode up to 4.6 mg cm–2. Graphic abstract B/N–codoped hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets with abundant micropores and low–range mesopores are reported as sulfur host to boost the polysulfide confinement via both physical restriction and Lewis acid–base interaction for high–performance lithium–sulfur batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium–sulfur batteries Porous carbon nanosheets B/N–codoped Lewis acid–base Bimodal–pore structure 1 Introduction The development of portable electronic devices and electric vehicles drives the pursuing of advanced high–energy density batteries to satisfy the energy requirements [1–4]. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) battery is a new type of secondary battery system that employs metallic Li as the anode and elemental sulfur or a sulfur–containing compound as the cathode. During discharge/charge cycles, the two–electron conversion reaction from S to Li2S induces a theoretically specific capacity of 1675 mAh g–1 [5–8]. Consequently, the extremely high energy density of 2600 Wh kg–1 in theory can be realized [9,10], which has made Li–S battery an attractive alternative of next–generation high energy batteries, coupled with the natural abundance and environmental friendliness of sulfur [11–13]. In spite of the aforementioned advantages, there are also several obstacles relevant to the sulfur cathode that stands in the way of practical applications of Li–S batteries. First, the poor electronic conductivity of sulfur and its final reduced product, Li2S, results in slow charge transfer kinetics and low utilization of active materials [14,15]. Second, the whole conversion reaction involves complex lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), which can readily dissolve in the widely used ether–based electrolyte to form a shuttle effect [16–18]. The so–called shuttle effect further induces the irreversible deposition of insoluble sulfides on the electrode surface, resulting in increased interfacial resistances and rapid capacity decay during cycling. So far, great efforts have been contributed to upgrade the sulfur–based cathodes by focusing on improving the conductivity and alleviating the shuttling of LiPSs via physical confinement or/and chemical binding with the aid of various substrates. The early endeavors focus on immobilizing sulfur within the pores of conductive porous carbon via physical confinement to retard the polysulfide shuttle, and taking the advantage of high conductivity to improve the sulfur utilization [19,20]. For example, Nazar`s group [21,22] reported the pioneering work of highly ordered mesoporous carbon to provide abundant channels for fast Li+ transportation and effectively trap the LiPSs. While Gao and the coworkers [23,24] demonstrated the electrochemical reaction can be constrained inside the micropores to realize the enhanced long stability of sulfur cathode. Apart from the pore structures, the morphology also plays an important role in the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes. Carbon materials with one–dimensional or two–dimensional structure, i.e. carbon nanotubes [25–27] and graphene [28–30], were of great benefit to fabricate high–efficiency sulfur/carbon cathodes to the conductive network for faster electron/ion transportation. In particular, graphene and its derivatives enjoyed unique advantages in the development sulfur–based composites owing to high surface area, shortened transfer pathway of Li+ ions and excellent flexibility. However, the reported graphene–based materials were often prepared from the chemical oxidation of graphite involving strong oxidizer and concentrated acid. Thereby, the porous carbon nanosheets have gained extensive interest as a sulfur host due to the graphene–like structure and the low–cost, feasible preparation. For instance, Kang et al. [31] reported N–doped hierarchical porous carbon nanosheets with high specific surface area and pore volume to realize the high capacity and ultralow capacity loss of 0.051% per cycle at 1 C of the sulfur cathodes. In addition, Wu et al. [32] proposed a two–in–one host with superhierarchical cobalt–embedded N–doped porous carbon nanosheets to simultaneously reserve the soluble LiPSs and regulate the plating of metallic Li anode, thereby realizing excellent capacity retention. In fact, the confinement of soluble LiPSs within in the pores of porous carbon is usually too weak to prevent them from diffusing out, thereby leading to poor stability of sulfur/carbon cathodes. Fortunately, the interaction between carbon materials and sulfur species can be enhanced by surface modification with heteroatoms such as N, B, P, S [33–37]. These heteroatoms can not only improve the conductivity, but also produce effective adsorption toward sulfur species. Typically, the doped N atoms especially pyridinic–/pyrrolic–N with lone pair electrons can act as a Lewis–base site to interact with the strong Lewis–acid of terminal Li atom in LiPSs [38–40]. Similar to doped N atoms, the doped B atoms can serve as a Lewis–acid site to interact the polysulfide Lewis–base (i.e. B–S bond) [41,42]. Such strong chemical interactions between the heteroatoms and LiPSs endow the doped carbon materials with polar surface to chemically confine LiPSs for highly stable sulfur cathodes. Despite the great application of doped carbon in Li–S batteries, the complicate preparation processes and costly raw materials were often involved, especially the 2D carbon materials, like graphene [43–45], which was considered effective host materials of sulfur. Therefore, it is very necessary to explore novel and economical strategy to fabricate the doped 2D carbon host. Based on the above analysis, herein, we prepared B/N–codoped hierarchical porous carbon nanosheets (B–N–CSs) through direct pyrolysis the mixture of urea and boric acid with the presence of the polyethylene glycol surfactant. The as–prepared B–N–CSs show hierarchical porosity with high specific surface, bimodal–pore distribution (1.1 nm and 2.3 nm), and high doping content. Moreover, it can serve as an effective sulfur host with strong confinement of LiPSs via Li–N and B–S interactions based on Lewis acid–base theory. As a result, the S/B–N–CSs cathode with a 76 wt% sulfur content exhibits high sulfur utilization, outstanding rate performance, and long–lasting cycle life. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of B–N–CSs host and S/B–N–CSs composite Typically, the mixture of urea (CO(NH2)2, 5 g), boric acid (H3BO3, 0.15 g), and polyethylene glycol (PEG–2000, 0.5 g) were dissolved in 50mL of deionized water under stirring, and the solution was dried on a heating mixer to prepare a dry gel precursor. Then, the precursor was placed in a tube furnace, and treated at 900 °C for 2 h at a ramp rate of 10°C min−1 under Ar atmosphere to produce B/N–codoped carbon nanosheets, which was marked as B–N–CSs. N–doped carbon (N–CSs) was obtained via the same procedure without adding boric acid. To prepare the sulfur composite, sulfur powder and B–N–CSs (or N–CSs) were ground together with a mass ratio of 3:1, and placed in a sealed Teflon reactor filled with Ar, followed by a heat treatment at 155 °C for 12 h. 2.2 Structural characterization The phase purity of the carbon samples was identified by X–ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE) with 2θ range of 10o–80o. Sulfur content was confirmed by thermal gravimetric analyzer (TGA, PE 4000). The chemical composition was confirmed by X–ray photoelectron spectra (XPS, ThermoFisher Scientific, ESCALAB250 Xi). The microstructure and morphology of the samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM 6701F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100). Brunauer–Emmett–Teller measurement using N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms was carried out on the JW–BK112 system. The thickness of the carbon layer of the sample was characterized by an Atomic Force Microscope (AFM, Agilent5500AFM/SPM). The graphitization degree of carbon materials was confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (Raman, INVIA) with a 532 nm excitation wavelength. 2.3 Electrochemical measurement To prepare the sulfur cathode, S/B–N–CSs or S/N–CSs, Super P and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVdF) were mixed at the weight ratio of 7:2:1 and dispersed in N–methyl–2–pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent to obtain the cathode slurry. Then, the slurry was cast onto the Al foil, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. Finally, the cathode film was punched into disks with a diameter of 12 mm with a typical sulfur loading of 1.4 mg cm–2. As for the cathodes with higher loadings, commercial carbon fiber paper was used as the current collector via the same preparation process. Li–S cells were assembled in the glove box with metallic lithium as anode and a Celgard 2400 membrane as separator. The employed electrolyte was composed of lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 1.0 M) and lithium nitrate additive (LiNO3, 2 wt%) in a mixed solvent of dimethyl ether (DME) and 1,3–dioxolane (DOL) (v/v, 1/1). The involved electrolyte amount was controlled at 10 µL mg–1 per sulfur. The discharge/charge tests were carried out using the Battery Testing System (NEWARE, Shenzhen) in the potential range of 1.7~2.8 V (vs. Li/Li+) at different C–rates from 0.1 C to 5.0 C (1 C = 1675 mA g–1). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) test with scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1 and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement from 10 MHz to 100 kHz with a 10 mV amplitude were performed with the electrochemical workstation (PARSTAT 2273). 2.4 Electrochemical kinetics evaluation N–CSs and B–N–CSs were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol, and then dropped onto a graphite felt (12 mm) to achieve a mass loading of ~0.5 mg cm–2, respectively. 20 µL of 0.5 M Li2S8–DME/DOL solution was dropped onto the material–loaded felt, and served as the electrode to assemble the symmetric cell by using two identical electrodes separated by a Celgard PP separator. CV tests at a potential range of –0.8~0.8 V with scan rate of 5 mV s–1 and EIS measurements at open circuit state from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz were performed. The precipitation of Li2S on the host surface was explored via chronoamperometry. Coin cells were assembled by using above N–CSs and B–N–CSs electrode as cathode, metallic Li as anode and PP membrane as separator. 20 µL of 0.2 M Li2S8/tetraglyme solution was dropped onto the cathode, and 20 µL of 1 M LiTFSI/tetraglyme was used as the anode electrolyte. The cells were galvanostatically discharged to 2.06 V at the current of 0.112 mA, and then kept potentiostatically at 2.05 V for the complete nucleation of Li2S on the N–CSs and B–N–CSs electrode. 3 Results and discussion As illustrated in Fig. 1 , the preparation of the B–N–CSs material was carried out by a one–step pyrolysis method reported previously [46]. Urea was used as the carbon and nitrogen source since it generated the graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets, which would guarantee the formation of two–dimensional (2D) structure of B–N–CSs. In addition, PEG surfactant also showed a structure–induced effect, and boric acid was used as the boron source for B–doping feature. The as–obtained B–N–CSs and N–CSs materials were then adopted as sulfur host to prepare S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composite via the typical melt–diffusion method. Fig. 2 (a) shows the XRD pattern of the as–prepared B–N–CSs and N–CSs materials. The typical broad peaks with 2θ at 26° and 44° indicated the disordered structure of the carbon materials. At the meantime, Raman spectra (Fig. S1) of the two samples present two main bands at 1354 cm–1 (D band) and 1591 cm–1 (G band). The higher I D /I G value of B–N–CSs (0.943) than that of N–CSs suggested the more disordered and defective structure due to the increasing doping heteroatoms. Further, SEM image of B–N–CSs in Fig. 2(b) clearly shows the graphene–like wrinkles, which confirms the formation of 2D graphene–like carbon nanosheets during the high temperature pyrolysis. Such a 2D structure was further demonstrated as cicada`s wings by TEM images in Fig. 2(c,d). Moreover, the corresponding elemental mapping (Fig. 2e) demonstrated the coexistence of C, N, and B elements and their uniform distribution in the B–N–CSs sample, which can be also confirmed by the elemental line distribution (Fig. S2). To precisely determine the graphene–like structure of B–N–CSs sample, the atomic force microscope (AFM) was conducted, and the thickness is determined as about less than 2.0 nm (Fig. S3), approximately 5~6 layers of graphene. In contrast, the N–CSs sample exhibits the stacked structure (Fig. S4a,b). The characterization results vividly demonstrated the 2D graphene–like structure of the as–prepared B–N–CSs sample. The phase composition of S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composites was identified by XRD. As seen from Fig. 3 (a), the diffraction peaks of the composites are well matched with the standard orthogonal sulfur crystal (PDF#08–0247) pattern, suggesting the existence of crystalline sulfur. The sulfur content in S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composites was confirmed as 76.1 wt% and 74.7 wt% respectively by TG test (Fig. 3b). In fact, the surface area and porous structure of carbon substrate are crucial for uniformly immobilize sulfur. As shown in Fig. 3(c,d), B–N–CSs sample possessed the typical type IV adsorption/desorption curve with the specific surface of ~520.9 m2 g–1, and showed a bimodal–pore structure concentrated at 1.1 nm and 2.3 nm. In fact, during the carbonization process, the reaction between urea and boric acid results in the formation of micro–/mesopores, thereby enhancing the surface area of the resulting B–N–CSs sample. After incorporating with sulfur, the S/B–N–CSs composite showed a decrease in specific surface area (395.2 m2 g–1) and the pore volume due to the occupation of sulfur within the pores. Nevertheless, the satisfying specific surface area of S/B–N–CSs can provide more active sites for improving sulfur utilization. In addition, the micropores and low–range mesopores contribute to the uniform dispersion of sulfur in the nanopores, which is further favorable for high sulfur utilization and the confinement of soluble LiPSs [47,48]. Therefore, the hierarchical porous B–N–CSs is expected as an effective host material for stable sulfur cathodes. To further identify the microstructure and morphology of S/B–N–CSs composite, SEM and TEM images were investigated in Fig. 4 . Benefiting from the highly porous and 2D graphene–like structure of B–N–CSs, sulfur was mainly confined within the pores, and the extra amount of sulfur dispersed uniformly on the surface. As seen from Fig. 4(a,b), there was no obvious aggregation of sulfur on the B–N–CSs surface. The graphene–like structure (Fig. 4c,d) of B–N–CSs host can still be observed in the S/B–N–CSs despite of the high sulfur content. The corresponding EDS mapping in Fig. 4(e) clearly demonstrate the uniform distribution of sulfur in S/B–N–CSs composite. X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further used to detect the heteroatom–doping feature of the as–prepared B–N–CSs and N–CSs samples, and also reveal the interaction between heteroatoms and sulfur in the S/B–N–CSs composite. The survey XPS spectra of N–CSs, B–N–CSs and S/B–N–CSs composite were shown in Fig. 5 (a). It clearly showed that C, N, and O signals were detected both in N–CSs and B–N–CSs samples, while B signal additionally appeared in B–N–GSs samples, implying the successful B/N co–doped feature of B–N–CSs sample. The elemental content (Table S1) can be obtained from the XPS results, and the sample with high content doped B/N heteroatoms was successfully prepared. In the case of B–N–CSs, the high–resolution C 1s spectrum (Fig. 5b) showed a strong peak at 284.6 eV, related to its carbon–carbon sp2 bond, and other two weaker peaks at 285.9 eV and 288.4 eV, related to the carbon–nitrogen bond and carbon–oxygen bond, respectively. Fig. 5(c) showed the high–resolution N 1s spectrum of B–N–CSs with three peaks at the binding energies of 398.2 eV, 398.5 eV, 400 eV, 401.7 eV, suggesting the coexistence of pyridinic N, N–B/N=B bond, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively. It was reported that the abundant doped N–configurations in carbon substrate showed strong binding energy toward LiPSs via the so–called Lewis acid–based interaction between the lone pair and Li+ ions, which benefits for enhancing the absorption and retention of soluble polysulfides within cathode side [41]. The N–doping feature can also be observed in N–CSs, as seen in Fig. S5. The refined B 1s spectrum (Fig. 5d) of B–N–CSs consisted of three peaks at the binding energies of 190.4 eV, 191.3 and 192.5 eV, corresponding to B–C, B=N and B–N bond, respectively, confirming the B–doping feature of B–N–CSs. After incorporating with sulfur, the original B–C and B–N/B=N bonds showed a shift to higher binding energy, which should be ascribed to the possible interaction between B atom and S atom due to the electron–deficient property of B atom. Further, the B/N co–doped feature in a carbon substrate can significantly improve its electronic conductivity due to the different electronegativity of B/N heteroatoms and C atoms [39,49]. S 2p of S/B–N–CSs was presented in Fig. 5(f). The former two peaks were ascribed to S–S bond (S 2p 3/2 at 163.8 eV, and S 2p 1/2 at 164.9 eV), while the later at higher binding energy were attributed to sulfurous (168.8 eV) and sulfate (169.8 eV) species. Such a trace of high–oxidation state sulfur species should be induced by the chemical interaction between sulfur and B–N–CSs material during the heating process [33,50,51]. In terms of the interaction with soluble LiPSs, it was believed that the doped N atom can act as a Lewis base due to its own lone pair to facilitate the interaction with Li+ through charge transfer, while the doped B atom also acts as a Lewis acid to enable the strong interaction with S n 2– [38], as illustrated in Fig. 5(e). In addition, the ability to confine LiPSs of B–N–CSs was further investigated by the static adsorption test. As shown in Fig. S6, the Li2S8/DME/DOL solution containing B–N–CSs changed into colorless after full adsorption, suggesting its strong adsorption towards soluble LiPSs. To directly demonstrate the interaction between the B–N–CSs sample and LiPSs, XPS spectra of the B–N–CSs sample after absorbing Li2S8 solution were recorded and concluded in Fig. 6 . The refined N 1s spectrum (Fig. 6a) suggested the coexistence of pyridinic N, N–B/N=B bond, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N at the binding energies of 398.6 eV, 399.5 eV, 400.8 eV and 403.9 eV, respectively. Compared with the pristine B–N–CSs sample, all the peaks showed an obvious shift to higher binding energy after interacting with LiPSs solution, which was probably originated from the interaction between N heteroatoms and Li ions in LiPSs. Meanwhile, Li 1s spectrum (Fig. 6b) was fitted by two peaks, which can be assigned to the Li–S bond (55.6 eV) in LiPSs and Li–N bond (54.9 eV) [44]. The presence of Li–N bonds evidently suggested the strong Lewis acid–base interaction between N heteroatoms in B–N–CSs sample and Li ions in LiPSs. In the case of B 1s spectrum in Fig. 6(c), all the peaks showed a shift to higher binding energy compared with the pristine B–N–CSs sample (Fig. 5d), which could be ascribed to the interaction between the electron–deficient B atom with polysulfide ions. In addition, in the S 2p spectrum (Fig. 6d), the peaks at 163.4 and 162.9 eV can be ascribed to the bridging S (SB 0) and terminal S (ST –1) in Li2S8 species, while the extra peaks at higher binding energies were attributed to thiosulfate (167.2 eV), sulfurous (168.7 eV) and sulfate species (169.9 eV). The oxidation of S species is in accord with the blueshift in both N 1s and B 1s spectra, which demonstrated the interaction between B–N–CSs sample and the soluble LiPSs. In order to evaluate the electrochemical performance of the S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composites, 2025 type button batteries were assembled. Firstly, the B–N–CSs and N–CSs materials were loaded onto a graphite felt electrode to assemble symmetric Li2S8–Li2S8 cells to detect the redox kinetics of mutual transformation between LiPSs. The CV curves were collected in the voltage range from –0.8 V to 0.8 V at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1. It is clear that the B–N–CSs electrode showed much higher peak current (Fig. 7 a), indicating excellent redox reaction kinetics probably due to the strong interactions between B/N heteroatoms and LiPSs [15,52]. In addition, the EIS curve at the open state in Fig. 7(b) suggested that the B–N–CSs electrode showed lower charge transfer resistance of ~72 Ω than that of the N–CSs electrode (~103 Ω), which was fitted using the equivalent circuit (Fig. S7). These compelling evidences demonstrated the rapid liquid–liquid conversion of LiPSs at the B–N–CSs surface. To further reveal the effects of different hosts on liquid–solid conversion of LiPSs, chronoamperometry curves of Li2S8/tetraglyme solution discharged at 2.05 V were shown in Fig. 7(c,d). It can be seen that the capacity of Li2S precipitation on B–N–CSs surface is 98 mAh g–1, higher than that on N–CSs surface (27.1 mAh g–1), which manifested the faster conversion from soluble LiPSs to insoluble Li2S. Therefore, the B–N–CSs host enables faster redox kinetics of both liquid–liquid and liquid–solid conversion of polysulfide chemistry. Representative CV curves of the S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composites were collected over a potential range of 1.7 to 2.8 V (vs. Li / Li+) at different scan rates from 0.1 mV s–1 to 0.6 mV s–1. As presented in Fig. 8 (a,c), the two composites showed two reduction peaks, consistent with the typical two–step redox reaction of a sulfur–based cathode. Specifically, at a low scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1, the cathodic peaks at 2.32 V and 2.05 V were observed, which should be ascribed to the conversion from sulfur to soluble high–order LiPSs, and then to insoluble sulfides, respectively. While the anodic process at the potential range of 2.3–2.4 V suggested the reversible conversion from insoluble sulfides to soluble LiPSs and further to sulfur [53]. It is worth noting that the CV curve of the S/B–N–CSs electrode exhibited higher peak currents and lower polarization, indicating higher sulfur utilization and fast conversion between LiPSs, which is consistent with the analysis of symmetric cells (Fig. 7a). In particular, the results of the fitted linearity (Fig. 8b and d) between the redox peak current and square root of scan rate show that the S/B–N–CSs composite possesses the higher slope than S/N–CSs composite, indicating the faster lithium on diffusion within the electrode [54]. Rate properties of S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composites were compared in Fig. 9 (a). S/B–N–CSs composite provided the reversible capacities of 1150, 810.6, 685.5, 588.1, 504.4 and 412.5 mAh g–1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5 C, respectively. More attractively, once the C–rate suddenly returned to 0.5 C, the discharge capacity can recover to 603.7 mAh g–1, which indicated that the structure of the S/B–N–CSs electrode remained highly stable even at high rates. In contrast, S/N–CSs showed poor performance with much lower capacities of 906.5, 637.2, 523.7, 428.5, 366.4, 288.3 mAh g–1. Moreover, the S/N–B–CSs composite showed stable discharge/charge potential platform along with the increasing C–rates (Fig. 9b). The better rate performance of S/B–N–CSs composite was mainly due to the promotion of electrochemical redox kinetics and the reduction of interfacial impedance. As shown in the EIS profile in Fig. S8, the S/B–N–CSs electrode possessed lower value of solution impedance and charge transfer impedance compared to the S/N–CSs composite. The relatively low resistances indicated the improved conductivity of S/B–N–CSs composite by B/N co–doping, which can effectively accelerate the redox reaction kinetics of the S/B–N–CSs electrode. Fig. 9(c,d) show the long–term cycle performance of S/B–N–CSs and S/N–CSs composited at different C–rates. In detail, the S/B–N–CSs composite delivered a high discharge capacity of 772.8 mAh g–1 at 0.5 C (Fig. 9c), and the discharge capacity remained at 400 mAh g–1 after 500 cycles, suggesting the average capacity decay rate was low as ~0.09% per cycle. While the S/N–CSs composite suffered the rapid capacity fading from 564.4 mAh g–1 to 115.6 mAh g–1 after 500 cycles. Even at a high C–rate of 1 C, the S/B–N–CSs composite exhibited superior cycle stability to S/N–CSs composite, and the average capacity decay rate is about 0.06% per cycle. Impressively, as concluded in the Table S2, the S/B–N–CSs composite showed remarkable cycle stability and rate capability even compared to the promising materials reported previously. Moreover, the outstanding electrochemical performance of S/B–N–CSs composite can be achieved even at high sulfur loadings. As shown in Fig. S9, the S/B–N–CSs electrode with the sulfur loading of 2.5 mg cm–2 realized the high initial discharge capacity of 779.3 mAh g–1 when cycled at 0.5 C, and remained as 683.7 mAh g–1 after 100 cycles, indicating a high capacity retention of ~87.7%. Furthermore, the capacity retention can achieve as 85.4% and 87.1% for the electrode with sulfur loading of 3.2 mg cm–2 and 4.6 mg cm–2, respectively. To further demonstrate the practical application potential of S/B–N–CSs cathode, the performance was revealed under lean electrolyte occupation. The results suggested that the S/B–N–CSs cathode still exhibited excellent electrochemical performance with the involved electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 5 µL mg–1 and 3 µL mg–1. Specifically, as shown in Fig. S10(a), the S/B–N–CSs cathode delivered the initial capacities of 700.5 mAh g–1 and 678.6 mAh g–1 with the electrolyte addition of 5 µL mg–1 and 3 µL mg–1, and remained 502.9 mAh g–1 and 448 mAhg–1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 C–rate, respectively, indicating the excellent cycle stability. More impressively, the cathodes showed no obvious decrease of discharge potential platforms (Fig. S10b) along with the decreasing electrolyte addition. The results convincingly suggest the potential of B–N–CSs as effective host for high performance sulfur cathodes. The aforementioned remarkable electrochemical performance including excellent rate capability and cycle stability of S/B–N–CSs can be attributed to the rationally designed structure of B–N–CSs host. Firstly, its 2D graphene–like structure is favorable for uniform distribution of active sulfur and fast electron and ion transportation. Secondly, the abundant micropore and low–range mesopores help to confine LiPSs within pores to retard their dissolution and diffusion. Thirdly, the B/N co–doped heteroatoms can not only improve the conductivity, but also enable the strong interaction between B–N–CSs and soluble LiPSs by B–S and N–Li bonds via Lewis acid–base interaction, which contributes much to suppress the shuttle effect. Moreover, such a desirable structure of B–N–CSs host showed promising stability during long–term discharge/charge cycling. To reveal the structure stability, the S/B–N–CSs composite was recovered from the Li–S cells after cycling at 0.5 C for 500 cycles. As shown in the TEM images in Fig. 10 (a,b), 2D carbon nanosheets can be clearly observed in spite of the coverage of numerous carbon nanoparticles, i.e. the conductive agent Super P, which demonstrated the good stability of B–N–CSs host. In addition, the EDS results in Fig. 10(c) evidently indicated the uniform distribution of sulfur active materials on the carbon substrate, which enabled the high sulfur utilization of S/B–N–CSs composite during prolonged electrochemical cycles. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have prepared B/N–codoped hierarchical porous carbon nanosheets (B–N–CSs) via the facile pyrolysis of the mixture of urea, boric acid and PEG surfactant. The as–prepared graphene–like B–N–CSs sample exhibits high specific surface area and bimodal pore structure of micropores (1.1 nm) and low–range mesopores (2.3 nm) for the uniform distribution of sulfur active materials. More importantly, the codoped B/N elements can enhance the polysulfide confinement by strong Li–N and B–S interaction based on Lewis acid–base theory. Such structural superiorities significantly suppress the shuttle effect by both physical and chemical confinement, and promote both the liquid–liquid and liquid–solid polysulfide conversion. When employed as sulfur host, the S/B–N–CSs cathode with high sulfur contene of 76 wt% shows a high specific capacity of 1150 mAh g–1 at 0.1 C, and 412.5 mAh g–1 even at 5 C. Besides, excellent stabilities can be realized up to 500 cycles at 0.5 C and 1 C with high capacity retention of ~87%, and the long–lasting cycle life can also be achieved for the sulfur cathode with high sulfur loading up to 4.6 mg cm–2. In view of the low cost of raw materials and facile preparation process, this work proposes a feasible strategy to prepare hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets with multiple doping feature for potential applications in high–performance Li–S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Carbon materials have shown remarkable usefulness in facilitating the performance of insulating sulfur cathode for lithium–sulfur batteries owing to their excellent conductivity and porous structure. However, the anxiety is the poor affinity toward polar polysulfides due to the intrinsic nonpolar surface of carbon. Herein, we report a direct pyrolysis of the mixture urea and boric acid to synthesize B/N–codoped hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets (B–N–CSs) as efficient sulfur host for lithium–sulfur battery. The graphene–like B–N–CSs provides high specific surface area and porous structure with abundant micropores (1.1 nm) and low–range mesopores (2.3 nm), thereby constraining the sulfur active materials within the pores. More importantly, the codoped B/N elements can further enhance the polysulfide confinement through strong Li–N and B–S interaction based on the Lewis acid–base theory. These structural superiorities significantly suppress the shuttle effect by both physical confinement and chemical interaction, and promote the redox kinetics of polysulfide conversion. When evaluated as the cathode host, the S/B–N–CSs composite displays the excellent performance with a high reversible capacity up to 772 mA h g–1 at 0.5 C and a low fading rate of ~0.09% per cycle averaged upon 500 cycles. In particular, remarkable stability with a high capacity retention of 87.1% can be realized when augmenting the sulfur loading in the cathode up to 4.6 mg cm–2.

coredata.dc:title: Boosting the polysulfide confinement in B/N–codoped hierarchically porous carbon nanosheets via Lewis acid–base interaction for stable Li–S batteries
